checkins.name: NESTUCCA
checkins.blurb: No joke one of the most beautiful roads I've been on. Winding, empty, covered in trees, accompanied by a river that's nearly shallow enough to be called a creek
checkins.firstPeeper: FUCK YES I GOT A PEEP

checkins.name: CAMPING BY THE NESTUCCA RIVER
checkins.blurb:
A beautiful and nearly deserted campsite. The only other campers were out hunting deer most of the day.

Despite riding through gorgeous autumn spectacles, I was sad when I got to the campsite. Lonely, tired, hungry.

Met Jon and Jonathan, two Navajo Indians who fed me by the fire and nourished my soul with good conversation. And their appreciation for each other. Jon, the cranky but kind old man with a titanium hip. Jonathan, the young hard-working helpful fellow with a good work ethic and head on his shoulders. Well, except for the anti-scientific theories he was parroting from YouTube. Wait, can onions really fight COVID? I'm gonna look real dumb when the research starts backing him.

Hunters. They tell stories of finding dead people around these parts. Murdered, or killed by driving off the side of the road. Yikes! I take it as a warning to redouble my caution on the twisting road. Also, to avoid murderers.

checkins.name: OREGON COAST HIGHWAY
checkins.blurb: JK I'm back on the fog hype. Made for some eerie riding today. #fogpog

checkins.name: NESTUCCA BAY WILDLIFE REFUGE
checkins.location: Nestucca Bay National Wildlife Refuge, OR
checkins.blurb: A cute little refuge, but unfortunately the best trails were closed off because some stupid trees decided to fall and block the way

checkins.name: BEN JONES BRIDGE
checkins.location: Otter Crest Loop, Depoe Bay, OR
checkins.blurb: The Pacific Coast Highway does not disappoint, even when there's all this fog up in your face

checkins.name: ANOTHER ECONOLODGE
checkins.blurb: The walls are scuffed the rug is ugly but at least my door locks so I don't have to worry about my crazy neighbor

checkins.name: SEA LION DOCKS
checkins.blurb: They actually bark like in the cartoons lmao

checkins.name: SIUSLAW NATIONAL FOREST
checkins.blurb: Highway 34 is so pleasantly twisty. I'd recommend it to any motorcycle rider in Oregon

checkins.name: DEB'S CAFE
checkins.blurb: A cute exterior and homey interior. I just had to make a stop when I saw that 1986 Honda Shadow parked out front. Turns out, it belongs to Deb's youngest son. Deb makes a mean omelette. Also I got to watch her get pissed at her grandson for not doing his math homework. 10/10 would recommend

checkins.name: EUGENE WHITEAKER INTERNATIONAL HOSTEL
checkins.blurb: Hol up -- Eugene is actually a super cute town? Like a quainter Portland. I think I might actually love it. And this cheap hostel is absolutely brimming with personality, just like every restaurant and store in the area

checkins.name: EUGENE WHITEAKER INTERNATIONAL HOSTEL
checkins.blurb: Just letting you know I'm still alive. Been working on this website and enjoying the town. I can't really get a full feel for the culture because of COVID, but even with limited human interaction and no group activities I'm digging it

checkins.name: PEEPS ARE LIVE!
checkins.blurb: New website feature! You can now "peep" a checkin by being the first one to click the PEEP button at the bottom of each checkin card. I've locked old checkins from allowing peeps, but I'll be opening them up for peeps randomly over time, so check back often. It's a great way for me to feel connected to whoever is following along, which kind of the point of this website (besides being a fun technical challenge)

checkins.name: WE LIVIN
checkins.location: Eugene Whiteaker International Hostel, Eugene, OR
checkins.blurb: I haven't moved. Working on this website is a lot of fun. Who knew that after riding off, the thing most effective at keeping me grounded would be work? I guess it's not work until someone makes you do it

checkins.name: COVID CONSCIOUS
checkins.location: Eugene Whiteaker International Hostel, Eugene, OR
checkins.blurb:
There's a young man, Cliff, who wears a beard that reminds me of Ian, an old co-worker. 

There's a young lady, Emily, who wants to be the world's next big prog rock pianist. She listens when I play guitar.

There were these two older gentlemen being insulting toward each other over nothing. "He started it!" I call them out for fighting like grade school kids. They settle down when they realize their attitudes only make them look foolish.

The hostel owner - also the head handyman - is a gruff middle aged gentleman with a heart similar to mine. He spent a few years working in schools in Europe, busked for a living for a while, and did odd jobs ranging from carpentry to web dev. He's trying to sell the place, and I semi-seriously consider it. He offers me his joint - I decline. COVID rules. I prefer sativa anyway.

I take pictures of places and sights but I shouldn't forget to take note of the people I meet. And I'm thankful I get to meet anyone at all, even if briefly, even as we sanitize the things we touch, cover our face holes, keep our distance like we're radioactive. It's not personal.

checkins.name: GOODBYE EUGENE
checkins.blurb: I'm on the road again. Plan is to book it to Redwood National Forest to spend the night.

checkins.name: I LOST MY BACKPACK
checkins.blurb:
üò≠üò≠üò≠üò≠üò≠üò≠üò≠
I LOST MY FREAKING BACKPACK

It was with me at the gas station and I must've forgotten to strap it back down. Either it never left the station or it somehow fell off my bike on the I-5. I checked back at the station but no luck :/

Luckily I only put replaceable, inexpensive items in there, as a precaution against this exact scenario. I feel pretty deflated though, and the time lost means I won't make it to Redwood tonight.

Whatever I'm over it. Let's be stoic

checkins.name: MARIE KONDO STOLE MY BACKPACK
checkins.blurb:
Got myself a nice hotel room as compensation for today going far less than perfect.

But losing the backpack is a blessing in disguise. I'm still learning how to pack most efficiently and what's really necessary to bring. Now there's a forcing function. If I restock on the lost stuff frugally, I might have room for a travel guitar.

I've been interested in these carbon-fiber detachable-neck guitars made by KLOS... and their headquarters would make a convenient next destination if I decide to go to Utah. Hm

checkins.name: FOREST ROUTE 17N49
checkins.blurb: Love me some deserted forest service roads

checkins.name: CALIFORNIA
checkins.blurb: yup

checkins.name: MAP IMPROVEMENTS
checkins.blurb:
Made some upgrades! Now you can click on a marker to automatically scroll to the corresponding check-in. Hovering over either a check-in card or map marker will highlight them both.

Huge shout outs to this raccoon I just met

checkins.name: 299 EAST
checkins.blurb: Just beautiful

checkins.name: MAN SHALL NOT LIVE BY CLIF BARS AND BEEF JERKY ALONE
checkins.blurb: but I sure as hell can try

checkins.name: FROM ONE NUTJOB TO ANOTHER
checkins.blurb:
Am I crazy? Who does this - jumps on a bike with only a vague plan and leaves his life behind?

Don't get me wrong, this stunt I'm pulling is freaking awesome. But I work hard to stave off the loneliness and the creeping doubts and sometimes I wonder if I thought this through enough. Today was rough and filled with questions.

But tonight at the campsite I met three bikers with a diverse set of motorcycles - an old-school V-Strom (pre-beak), a Harley Dynah Street Bob, and a frankenstein project dirt bike that at one point was some sort of Honda (I think?). Jeff, Thomas, and Chris. Cherry and friendly af. Thomas pulls up a metal pannier by the fire for me to sit on. I pull it back a couple more feet. COVID rules. And what a surprise - they have no plans and no dates either! They're hitting the coast tomorrow and just gonna mosey on wherever the wind takes them. Thomas is a software dev like me, and Jeff even lives on the bike like I do. I lay down the questions and we talk it through. I get recommendations, stories, laughs. Lots of laughs. These guys are nuts. Jeff gives me a sticker that says "Go fast, don't die".

I wanted to feel sane. I still feel crazy. But at least I'm not alone.

checkins.name: RACE TO RENO
checkins.blurb: Black bike best bike

checkins.name: WHAT'S YOUR FAVORITE GENRE OF MUSIC
checkins.blurb: and why is it LoFi

checkins.name: LOOSE CHAINZ
checkins.blurb: Luckily there's a shop in Reno that can help me out as soon as I get there. But damn this chain is loose! That's what 4 days full of riding gets you apparently

checkins.name: MINIMAL MAINTENANCE
checkins.blurb: The best part about this trip is being able to just take an exit that looks cool whenever the spirit moves me

checkins.name: I HAVE A FEELING WE AREN'T IN SEATTLE ANYMORE
checkins.blurb:
Man, the people that work at motorcycle shops are really cool. Feels like bikers are a super friendly bunch if you're "in". I'm glad I'm in. This is my tribe! Well, one of them. 

The I-80 stretches as far as the eye can see in a straight line. I think they call it the 80 because that's actually the speed limit for most of it. First time I've ever seen a speed limit that high. Kinda wish I had a bigger bike - the ol NC, full cargo, struggles against the wind sometimes.

At around 6 the sun steps behind a mountain and the temperature drops abruptly. At around 6:20 the bugs come out, and I can feel them kamikaze against my jeans and jacket. Put your visor down. I don't care how beautiful the twilight is.

Elko is busier than I thought it would be! One of the bike shop guys I mentioned in the first paragraph gave me a recommendation for a food place called The Star, so I decide to check it out. I step inside, and it's completely packed. Not a mask in sight. There's some hand sanitizer by the door, and hilariously it's empty. I leave. COVID rules.

checkins.name: LAMOILLE
checkins.blurb: Another recommendation from the guys at the bike shop. I didn't have much time to explore since I'm trying to make it to Salt Lake City today. Worth a stop though, especially considering Nevada has been mostly a drive-through state so far
checkins.firstPeeper: lets see if the limit is really 40 chara

checkins.name: GOOD MOOD IDK
checkins.blurb: Along with the check, my server just brought me this tortilla chip topped with cinnamon and whipped cream and I'm frEAKING OUT

checkins.name: U TAH
checkins.location: Quality Inn Downtown, Salt Lake City, UT
checkins.blurb: no u tah

checkins.name: NEW CHAIN WHO DIS
checkins.location: Moto Station, Salt Lake City, UT
checkins.blurb: Went in for new tires. Re-evaluated my chain, and decided I needed a new one of those too. Really hate that they didn't have sprockets in stock too, but my current one isn't too bad and should hold together until the next major city.

checkins.name: KLOS
checkins.blurb:
Holy shit I pulled the trigger and bought one of these

The one I got is full carbon fiber, travel sized, and can disassemble into a backpack-sized pack

The guys at the shop were so cool! They gave me a full tour of their operation, listened to me play, answered all my questions, and even gave me a free T-shirt and sticker

checkins.name: AVOIDING THE STORM
checkins.blurb:
Yesterday was great. Finally had a real campfire with Mark and Patrick at Jaycee Park Campground. Loving the new guitar. Met some dirt bikers and helped them jump start one of their bikes. I guess dealing with a dead battery back in September payed off.

There's a major winter storm warning going on right now in this area, so I holed up in a hostel nearby to avoid the rain and snow. Will probably be grounded tomorrow as well since I'd rather not be out in freezing temperatures. Black ice is bad enough for cars.

checkins.name: "PRACTICE
checkins.blurb: or practice your excuses"

checkins.name: PROTOTYPES
checkins.blurb: I haven't pushed any changes to the website lately, mostly because I've been busy prototyping a GoPro GPS pathing feature. Speaking of prototypes, here's a musical one
checkins.firstPeeper: STREAK ENDED ALSO WHAT IS THIS VERT VID

checkins.name: MILL CREEK
checkins.blurb:
Fewer tourists, more locals.

There's a cave hidden in plain sight if you look to your right at the canyonside as you're heading back to the parking lot. I feel an overwhelming urge to camp in it.

checkins.name: MY CAVE
checkins.location: a cave just off Mill Creek Trail, Moab, UT
checkins.blurb:
The full moon is so bright tonight that my headlamp barely makes a difference.

The river murmurs and even talks sometimes, I swear! Moonlight bounces off the twists in the creek, and it looks like eyes are watching. I even walked out there with my fight stick in hand to ward off whatever it was. Not sure what the plan was, honestly.

Did I mention I recruited a fight stick? This thing is a freaking longsword. I was practicing my swings earlier. What am I so afraid of? Well, wildlife. I've taken all the proper bear safety precautions (you know, for all the desert bears) but I don't know if there's anything else out there. Coyotes? Shit. I don't know. This stick probably wouldn't make a difference in a fight, but it does make me feel better.

Claudia, a hostel friend, spotted this cave when we were hiking the Mill Creek Waterfall Loop earlier today. It's hidden in plain sight in the canyonside, far off enough that most people aren't paying close enough attention to see it. We crossed the creek to explore it - me, Claudia, and David. Other David.

Other David is a seeker. He's two years younger than me. He ditched his church a few years ago and is on a quest for highest truth. He's a thoughtful guy, not content with small talk, and so instead we try to define love and the soul. I'm richer for it. Claudia is a masseuse. I helped her set up her business address with Google and SquareSpace. She's working from the hostel, taking tourist clients in the city. No funny business. We talk about how she protects herself from weirdos.

The fire I started is just red coals now. Soon it'll start getting cold in my little cave. Seriously, what an awesome little cave.

Man, some interesting people at the Lazy Lizard. Bill might have been my favorite. He's a techie troubadour like me! He's older (pushing 50 maybe) and likes to build webapps that track location history and download maps directly to your phone. He recommends I switch from Google Maps to Leaflet, and we bond over GeoJSON. Amazing! It seems like a silly thing to bond over, until you think about what it really means to both of us: an intersection between exploration and tech, two of our shared passions.

Bill even showed me how to fashion a weed bowl out of a soda can, which came in handy tonight. Actually, now that I think about it, weed is probably why I was stupid paranoid about coyotes earlier. Or maybe it's the Halloween spirit? Oof! It's definitely getting colder in here. I should sleep. Without a sleep mask, I'm forced to get up with the sun. I used to have a sleep mask, but... it was in the backpack. Keep forgetting to replace it.

checkins.name: LANDMARKS
checkins.location: Arches and Canyonlands National Parks, UT
checkins.blurb:
Yesterday was the 1 month anniversary of me being on the road, plus I woke up in a cave and then hit 10k on the odometer

Amazing
checkins.firstPeeper: Just say no to the streak. Uber

Feels like the right day to binge the entire Switchfoot discography

And by "entire" I mean The Legend of Chin through Oh Gravity

checkins.name: GRAND CANYON INN & MOTEL

checkins.name: GRAND CANYONEERING
checkins.location: Mather Point Overlook, Grand Canyon, AZ

checkins.name: THE HECKIN' CHONK CANYON
checkins.location: Angel Bright Trail, Grand Canyon, AZ

checkins.name: IT BEARS THE REMINDER
checkins.location: Grand Canyon Inn Restaurant, Valle, AZ
checkins.blurb:
OK, we need to talk about the Grand Canyon. It's like the biggest geological feature I've ever laid eyes on besides the freaking ocean. It's got more greenery to it than I saw in the canyons in Utah - which is a plus in these PNW-accustomed eyes - and the multi-day hike to the river and back is a tantalizing challenge that I've bookmarked for a later time.

Honestly, it was sensorial and emotional overload after a point. Maybe my heart, or my spirit, or whatever it is, isn't wide open enough to let all the light in. Am I broken?  Is my rational grip on reality so tight that I've blotted out the sublime?

Nah. That's just talk. I've been struck by many things in the last 36 days, things that make me laugh manically and whoop into my helmet and string together expletives as creatively as I can. It's just hard to be fully appreciative when I'm running low on sleep (mild insomnia, my arch nemesis!). You learn, after years of living in an emotional human, to have a checklist for when your emotions feel off. Am I tired? Hungry? Thirsty? Lacking in exercise? Sick or in pain somewhere? Our physical bodies are, for the most part, responsible for the state of our brains. It's an obvious fact, but it bears the reminder. At least, for me.

Unrelated but - what better way to appreciate this country than to visit the Grand Canyon, eat some apple pie, and watch an election unfold?

checkins.name: TEGENWIND
checkins.blurb:
Strong crosswinds today keeping me in 5th gear.

Wish I could've stayed at the Grand Canyon longer but a storm's brewing, and they're expecting snow. I'm Phoenix bound today.

checkins.name: SAGUARO
checkins.blurb: don't drink the cactus juice

checkins.name: ONESON TUCSON
checkins.location: Red Lion Inn & Suites, Tucson, AZ
checkins.blurb: redson blueson
checkins.firstPeeper: I do not like green eggs and ham

checkins.name: MOUNT LEMMON
checkins.firstPeeper: Tell me, dear brother - did you find it?

checkins.name: WHEN LIFE GIVES YOU LEMMONS
checkins.blurb:
Mount Lemmon was disgusting. One full hour of twisting highway (with even an occasional switchback!) grants you gradually more spectacular views of a mountainside that's way too green for this kind of desert, peppered with boulders and rock formations that look almost intentionally arranged, all set under the kind of vastly empty sky and maximally distant horizon that only the desert offers. It's like someone mashed together the best parts of Washington, Utah, and Arizona. Make sure you catch the sunset on the way down. I've never seen a mountainside quite so pink set against a sky so deeply orange.

At the top is a little community called Summerhaven, with a gift shop, cabins, a few eateries. I park just outside the Cookie Cabin and sit for a while lamenting how crowded the dessert shop is. I want a cookie. But I'm not going in. COVID rules. A young lady (early college aged, I'm guessing) notices me on the bike and waves. "Can I get on the back??" "Sure," I joke. She's serious though, and promptly gets up and walks over. "Uhhh, I don't have a helmet for you..." "Can you just go slow? I haven't been on a bike in ten years. Lately I've been ranting about wanting to ride one." I allow it. She puts on her mask, hops on the back, and we take a short joyride to the ski resort and back. Her name's Madelyn, and she comes from a family of Harley riders. She puts the ride on Snapchat and asks me to do a wheelie. Freakin' zoomers.

Near the summit, take a right and continue past the fire district. A primitive rocky road begins. Old Mt Lemmon Road slithers northeast down the mountain, so thoroughly twisty you'd think it was carved by a river. I can't resist the call, but I also can't confidently break 15mph in this rough terrain. My Honda NC700X lies partway between adventure and street bike. I've got the tires and suspension to do this kind of thing, but the lackluster ground clearance and medium weight class mean I should stay away from anything you wouldn't classify as "light off-roading". Trust me. I nearly died in the Yakima desert proving this to myself. 

Fifteen minutes down the rocky road, I run into an older gentleman on a red Honda CRF250 going up the mountain. We stop next to each other with grins and knowing looks in our eyes. We're part of the same tribe. During solitary moments like these, meeting someone who's on the same kind of journey instantly generates a kind of provisional familiarity - an intimacy, even. "Turn your bike all the way off," he advises, implying he wants more than just a cursory exchange of pleasantries. I oblige. He takes a look at my bike, and I know exactly what he's thinking. "Don't worry," I say, "I know not to bite off more than I can chew." His CRF is a much better fit for this kind of trail. With a skeptical glance, he points to an angry pile of rocks on the side of the road and says "THAT'S what the road looks like about half a mile down. Rocks so sharp they'll tear your tires rim to rim." Gulp. I assure him that I'm not going much further and that I know my limits - though I'm grateful for the heads up. We trade stories.

As the sun sets and I head back down the way I came in, I stop at a pullout for a picture. The family in the car ahead of me looks... a little off? I ask them if they're OK, and the young father says "yeah we're good - just having a little throw-up problem" as he herds his toddler back into the car. A kid pokes her head out the window, sees my GoPro, and asks "Do you have a YouTube channel??" "Yeah!" "Are you famous??" "Nope!" "Oh." Freakin' zoomers.

checkins.name: ARIZONA'S ALRIGHT
checkins.blurb:
Not complaining

Kinda hot though
